title: Btcalysis
author: Btcalysis
content: Russian finance ministry, central bank weigh crypto trading pilot for top-tier investorshttps://crypto.news/russian-finance-ministry-central-bank-weigh-crypto-trading-pilot-for-top-tier-investors/What kind of news is this?From the news only top-tier investors, with a $250,000 minimum asset holding will be allowed. It is also an experiment which may not take more than 5 years.Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Russia are negotiating about it.When Russians are busy trading cryptocurrencies. This could only mean they have been missing the tax they supposed to have earned. I hope they will begin the experiment and see how positive it will become.

comments.author: freedomgo
comments.body: Since this is a central bank initiative, it’s likely that banks will manage it under the central bank’s supervision. With a $250K minimum, transactions will probably be limited to high-net-worth individuals and institutions rather than everyday users.It should be safer through banks since, in general, banks have insurance coverage, but how that applies to crypto is still unclear. It’s something worth looking into, especially in terms of how funds are protected in case of hacks or insolvency.

This is only the information about it yet.I read more articles about this topic, and it turns out that the main reason the central bank set a $250K minimum balance is to mitigate risk. The assumption is that if someone holds that kind of portfolio, they are already experts in their field and are expected to understand market volatility and know how to manage risks effectively.

comments.author: stadus
comments.body: Quote from: Dunamisx on March 12, 2025, 02:04:27 PMWhy is this kind of decision coming from the government? Why are they being selective in using such criteria on this, am sure this is not a deal that is going to stay long because those they have targeted this for will eventually see no benefits from it than being  affected by their regulations.This is just a pilot program, so it can still be revised over time if there’s a need for changes.As for its purpose, it’s pretty obvious that they want to minimize risks, as big traders are more capable of handling market fluctuations.In short, the government doesn’t want the responsibility of educating small traders who might end up losing money due to the market’s volatility and unpredictability.Quote from: Dunamisx on March 12, 2025, 02:04:27 PMAlso from other end of this, we should see it as a way of continuity for the adoption of bitcoin and it recognition by the governments, this time, they are only implementing on this in favour of the big holders, what about the consideration for the other people.They can still trade on exchanges operating outside Russia, but the catch is, those platforms aren’t regulated by the government. So while it’s still possible, it comes with more risks since they won’t have the same level of protection or oversight.

comments.author: coupable
comments.body: Quote from: Dunamisx on March 12, 2025, 02:04:27 PMAlso from other end of this, we should see it as a way of continuity for the adoption of bitcoin and it recognition by the governments, this time, they are only implementing on this in favour of the big holders, what about the consideration for the other people.Well, Russia has certainly begun to show signs of considering draft laws and proposals to partially or completely regulate the sector, influenced by what is happening globally, especially in the American sphere, where both the United States and Brazil have begun accumulating Bitcoin reserves. At the same time, we must understand that Russia cannot allow full recognition of everything that would enable financial freedom for citizens and companies. Russia knows that the number of crypto users in Russia is constantly growing, but it would prefer to exclude them from the economic cycle rather than recognize them and impose taxes. Well, let's see how many people in Russia own at least $250,000 worth of Bitcoin.

comments.author: avikz
comments.body: I do not see much positive in this news. Banks will do the trading, they will use their citizens money to do that. Everything will be controlled at bank's end. Government will get taxes out of every trade and then on the total income. Nothing positive except some liquidity flow into the market. I hope Russia opens up their market for cryptocurrency. That will be a real change and a positive one. If banking controls everything related to crypto for the big-pocket investors, then it's not a real change!

I expect it to be a rush for validation in Africa soon with our heads of states keying in, owing to the way Africa leaders kontow to foreign ideas. This current Bitcoin circle is hugely favourable to this industry, and bullish sentiments are obvious everywhere. Anyone shorting for the long term because of the dip they see now is preparing themselves for losses.

comments.body: I see the same signs we've been seeing coming from different governments. They want more control. This is a centralized platform where they can control the "traders" funds therefore monitor and tax them easier. There is also a possibility that my theory which I posted here recently exists elsewhere (among governments) and they look into doing what US government tries to do which is market manipulation to cover budget deficit
